newsitem.title: ANGOLA: After 1,000 days, Angola's peace could crumble.
newsitem.headline: After 1,000 days, Angola's peace could crumble.

text.p: Angola's peace process marked 1,000 days on Saturday amid growing signs the country is drifting toward renewed conflict.
"I would say this is the most crucial point in the peace process," said one official close to Angola's peace negotiations. "This is our last chance to secure peace in Angola."
On November 20, 1994, the Angolan government and the former rebel movement UNITA, the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, signed a peace agreement in the Zambian capital, Lusaka.
The agreement ended nearly two decades of civil war and has brought the country the longest period of peace since a war of independence was launched against the Portuguese in the 1960s.

But recent weeks have shown a rapid deterioration in the peace process with government military incursions into UNITA territory and foot dragging on remaining crucial elements of the Lusaka agreement.
The former rebels were given until Friday to respond to a number of Security Council demands or face possible sanctions.

On Friday U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan, appeared to clear the way for punitive sanctions by the Security Council, saying last-minute "half-hearted concessions by UNITA, under pressure and on the eve of Security Council deliberations, are no longer acceptable".
But diplomats say Annan wanted to hold off sanctions while U.N. officials in Angola verified recent promises made by UNITA.
Diplomats in Luanda said the former rebels were likely to be hit with sanctions soon, possibly after a two-week grace period.
The atmosphere among the key negotiators in the peace process has recently turned sour with daily admissions in private by diplomats and officials that patience is wearing thin.
Officials of the U.N. Observer Mission in Angola (MONUA) stress that the Lusaka agreement can still be implemented and point toward the successes of the U.N. action in Angola.
"Basically after 1,000 days our triumph is that the ceasefire has held," said David Wimhurst, spokesman for MONUA.
"In that sense we have saved the lives of thousands. We oversaw the establishment of a unity government, the integration of the army and the police, all things called for in the Lusaka agreement.
"Of course the bad news is that we are still here," Wimhurst continued. "This mission was supposed to end six months ago."
One symbol of the Lusaka agreement can be found in Eugenio Ngolo "Manuvakola", the man who signed the agreement for UNITA leader Jonas Savimbi in 1994.

Ngolo has not been seen in public in close to a year. Though UNITA officials in Luanda deny it, Ngolo is strongly rumored to be under house arrest in the UNITA-held highland city of Bailundo and has fallen out of favor with Savimbi.
